why you might want to build a

probably the best reason for um
introducing a distributed team is that
you're able to go where the people are
so you can hire the best talent no
matter where they are in the world
you're not constrained by the location
that you're currently operating out
of sometimes hiring people is cheaper as
well and I'm not talking about
Outsourcing I'm not a fan of Outsourcing
I'm talking about going where the people
are and those particular locations
having a lower cost of living so for us
for example Melbourne has a lower cost
of living than San Francisco so we're
able to hire the same quality Engineers
there at a much lower price and we able
to channel those savings into travel so
we don't save money collectively as a

that we can bring our teams together and
again that's another kind of overlay of
the things that we're talking about
today another big benefit that I in
particular see from distributed teams is
you were able to have parallel hiring
pipelines so instead of growing Say by
two people a month in a single location
with five sites you can grow by 10 a
month so it's a really
uh strong feature of distributed teams
and something that's very attractive to
us uh as an organization in in high
growth and because you are in high
growth with multiple locations you've
der risked that growth so if one of
those markets slows down for some reason
your other so take say we've got five
offices if one of those slows down then
four of them are able to take up that
slack so maybe you're only hiring by
eight a month rather than 10 a month so
you've effectively drisk your growth
across all of those
offices from a practical point of view
as an engineer um with multiple
distributed teams you're able to do

for example in Melbourne so I'm on call

Loosely workday time shifted two hours

um and the same for their
day by creating smaller offices too what
you're able to do is you're able to I've
written up there stay smaller for longer
but what I effectively mean is that you
you can Shard your culture so rather
than having a 500 person office say if
you have 10 50 people offices you've got
a smaller group of people working in
each location so you're kind of um
becoming a little bit immune to the

those larger organizations so you can
have the same number of people but you
can have smaller teams working together
that get on really well together new
sites also allow you to try a lot of

different branding for example or
different colors of walls and layouts of
of offices and things like that so
you've got the freedom to experiment
without actually changing your core site
and without actually doing everything at
once so I've alluded to the positives
but there are
drawbacks if teams are spread up across
multiple time zones there are barriers
to productivity one of the things that
we've seen recently is that if um so say
someone in San Francisco gets stuck on
something at 10:00 in the morning
they've got to wait until 3:00 p.m. for
Melbourne to wake up to unblock them so
you can get a lot of productivity drain
and it can be a killer for both
productivity and team morale if they're
waiting for 5 hours with nobody to kind
of Unblock their pull request for
example so time zone overlap plays
heavily into the way you structure your
teams having people around the world is
great for product velocity product
managers love it but it's not so great
for engineers who want to kind of always
be really
responsive and so what you end up with
them is that they feel compuls a
compulsion to always be on and to always
be available and really easy to like
answer a slack message over breakfast
because you know New York's awake and
they're going to go home in half an hour
or you might send something off at the
end of your day so that San Francisco
can pick it up so that the next day
you've got an answer when you come into
work it's very easy to do that so you
need to bring in both technical blockers
for this so for example we encourage
everybody when they start to set up
snooze in slack so that they don't get
notified overnight uh as well as build a
culture that reinforces that it's both
not expected or Des desired for people
to do that and as a leader you're going
to have to model that behavior so that
people see that you're doing that
also Staffing within a distributed
organization becomes a lot harder as
well you need to align your recruiting
efforts to not just the local conditions
but you need to uh take into account the
needs of those local
teams as well as ensuring you've got
kind of a globally optimized program of
work across all of your sites which can

Stark Melbourne was super high and it

what the local issues are that those
people are concerned about um and be
across that so you've got more than one

a distributed
organization maintaining culture in a
